overview: Employment status (worker, employee, self-employed, director or contractor) affects employment rights and employer responsibilities in the workplace
title: Employment status

table.body:
In employment law a person's employment status helps determine their rights and an employer's responsibilities.

%In tax law a person may have a different employment status - [check what this is](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/calcs/esi.htm "Employment Status Indicator"){:rel="external"} with HM Revenue & Customs and find out about [deducting National Insurance contributions](/national-insurance-contributions-nics-for-employers/overview "National Insurance contributions for employees") for employees.%

The main types of employment status include:

- [worker](/employment-status/worker "Worker")
- [employee](/employment-status/employee "Employee")
- [self-employed](/employment-status/selfemployed "Self-employed")
- [director](/employment-status/director "Director")
- [types of contractors](/employment-status/contractor "Contractor")

Sometimes it isn't easy to work out someone's employment status. Contact Acas (or the [Labour Relations Agency](http://www.lra.org.uk/ "Labour Relations Agency"){:rel="external"} if you work in  Northern Ireland) if you need advice on employment status and a person’s employment rights and their employer’s responsibilities. 

$C
**Acas helpline**  
08457 47 47 47  
Monday to Friday 8am to 8pm  
Saturday 9am to 1pm
$C

As a last resort you can take a case to an [employment tribunal](/employment-tribunals/taking-a-case-to-an-employment-tribunal "Employment tribunal") (known as an [industrial tribunal](http://www.employmenttribunalsni.co.uk/ "industrial tribunal"){:rel="external"} in Northern Ireland) or a court and they'll make the final [decision](/employment-status/legal-decisions-on-employment-status "Legal decisions on employment status") on someone's employment status for employment law purposes.

*[Acas]: Advisory, Conciliation and Arbitration Service
table.title: Overview

table.body:
The main requirements for being a 'worker' are that:

- a person has a [contract](/employment-contracts-and-conditions "Employment contracts and conditions") to do work or services personally - they may have only a limited right to send someone else to do, or sub-contract, the work
- a person isn't doing the work as part of their own limited company where the 'employer' is actually a customer or client

##Employment rights
Workers are entitled to certain employment rights, for example:

- to get the [National Minimum Wage](/your-right-to-minimum-wage "Your right to the minimum wage")
- protection against unlawful deductions from wages
- the statutory minimum level of paid [holiday](/holiday-entitlement-your-rights "Holiday entitlement")
- the statutory minimum length of [rest breaks](/rest-breaks-at-work "Rest breaks at work")
- not to work more than [48 hours on average per week](/maximum-weekly-working-hours "Maximum weekly working hours") or to opt out of this right if they choose
- protection against unlawful [discrimination](/discrimination-your-rights "Discrimination")
- protection for ['whistleblowing'](/whistleblowing "Whistleblowing") (reporting wrongdoing in the workplace)

They may also be entitled to:

- [Statutory Maternity Pay](/statutory-maternity-pay "Statutory Maternity Pay")
- [Ordinary Statutory Paternity Pay](/ordinary-statutory-paternity-pay "Ordinary Statutory Paternity Pay")
- [Statutory Sick Pay](/statutory-sick-pay-ssp "Statutory Sick Pay")

^Agency workers have specific [rights](/agency-workers-your-rights/overview "Agency workers: your rights") from the first day at work.^

Workers usually aren't entitled to:

- minimum notice periods if their employment will be ending (eg if an employer is dismissing them)
- protection against [unfair dismissal](/dismissal/unfair-and-constructive-dismissal "Unfair dismissal")
- the right to request [flexible working](/flexible-working "Flexible working")
- [time off for emergencies](/time-off-for-dependants "Time off for family and dependants")
- [Statutory Redundancy Pay](/redundant-your-rights/statutory-redundancy-pay- "Statutory Redundancy Pay")

##Casual or irregular work: working out employment status

If someone does casual or irregular work for a business and the majority of the statements below apply to them, it's likely they're a worker:

- they occasionally do work for a specific business 
- the business doesn't have to offer them work and they don't have to accept it - they only work when they want to
- their contract with the business uses terms like 'casual', 'freelance', 'zero hours', 'as required' or something similar
- they had to agree with the business’s terms and conditions to get work (either verbally or in writing)
- they are under the supervision or control of a manager or director
- they can't send someone else to do their work
- the business deducts tax and National Insurance contributions from their wages
- the business provides materials, tools or equipment they need to do the work
table.title: Worker

table.body:
An employee is someone who works under an [employment contract](/employment-contracts-and-conditions/overview "Employment contracts"). 

^A person may be an employee in employment law but HM Revenue & Customs may regard them as having a different [employment status for tax purposes.](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/calcs/esi.htm “Employment Status Indicator”){:rel="external"}^

##Employment rights
All employees are workers, but an employee has extra employment rights and responsibilities than a worker who isn't an employee. 

These rights include all of the rights [workers](/employment-status/worker "Worker") have and:

- [Statutory Sick Pay](/statutory-sick-pay-ssp "Statutory Sick Pay")
- [maternity](/maternity-leave "Maternity Leave"), [paternity](/paternityleave "Paternity Leave") and [adoption](/adoption-leave "Adoption Leave") leave and pay
- minimum notice periods if their employment will be ending (eg if an employer is dismissing them)
- protection against [unfair dismissal](/dismissal/unfair-and-constructive-dismissal "Unfair dismissal")
- the right to request [flexible working](/flexible-working "Flexible working")
- [time off for emergencies](/time-off-for-dependants "Time off for family and dependants")
- [Statutory Redundancy Pay](/redundant-your-rights/statutory-redundancy-pay- "Statutory Redundancy Pay")

Some of these rights require a minimum length of [continuous employment](/continuous-employment-what-it-is "Continuous employment") before an employee qualifies for them. An employment contract may state how long this qualification period is.

##Working out employment status for an employee
If the majority of the statements below apply to someone who works for a business, it's likely they're an employee:

- they're required to work regularly unless they're on leave (eg [holiday](/holiday-entitlement-your-rights/overview "Holiday entitlement"), [sick leave](/taking-sick-leave "Taking sick leave") or [maternity leave](/maternity-leave "Maternity Leave"))
- they're required to do a minimum number of hours and expect to be paid for time worked
- a manager or supervisor is responsible for their workload, saying when a piece of work should be finished and how it should be done
- they can't send someone else to do their work
- the business deducts tax and National Insurance contributions from their wages
- they get paid holiday
- they're entitled to contractual or Statutory [Sick,](/statutory-sick-pay-ssp "Statutory Sick Pay") [Maternity,](/statutory-maternity-pay "Statutory Maternity Pay") or [Paternity](/ordinary-statutory-paternity-pay "Ordinary Statutory Paternity Pay") Pay 
- they can join the business's pension scheme
- the business's disciplinary and grievance procedures apply to them
- they work at the business's premises or at an address specified by the business
- their contract sets out redundancy procedures
- the business provides the materials, tools and equipment for their work
- they only work for the business or if they do have another job, it's completely different from their work for the business
- their contract, statement of terms and conditions or offer letter (which can be described as an ['employment contract'](/employment-contracts-and-conditions/overview "Employment contracts")) uses terms like 'employer' and 'employee'
table.title: Employee

table.body:
A person is self-employed if they're in business for themselves. They must tell HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC) as soon as possible if they're self-employed otherwise they may be fined.

Employment legislation does not generally cover self-employed people because they are, in effect, their own boss.

If a person is self-employed:

- they still have protection for their health and safety and, in some cases, protection against [discrimination](/discrimination-your-rights "Discrimination")
- their rights and responsibilities would be set out by the terms of the contract they have with your client

^HMRC may regard someone as self-employed for tax purposes but they might have a different status in employment law.^

*[HMRC]: HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: Self-employed

table.body:
Company directors run limited companies on behalf of shareholders.

Directors have different rights and responsibilities from employees:

* company directors are classed as office holders for tax and [National Insurance contribution](/national-insurance-contributions-nics-for-employers/overview "National Insurance contributions for employers") purposes
* the rights and duties of a director are different than for employees
* if a person does other work that’s not related to being a director, they may have an employment contract and get employment rights
table.title: Director

table.body:
A contractor can be:

- [self-employed](/employment-status/selfemployed "Self-employed")
- a [worker](/employment-status/worker "Employment status") or an [employee](/employment-status/employee "Employee") if they work for a client and are employed by an agency

If a contractor is an employee and they provide their services through a third party (eg their own limited company), an employer doesn't have to make [National Insurance contributions (NICs)](/national-insurance-contributions-nics-for-employers/overview "National Insurance contributions (NICs) for employers") or deduct PAYE.

There is a special scheme for self-employed contractors and sub-contractors working in the construction industry called the [Construction Industry Scheme (CIS).](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/cis/ "Construction Industry Scheme (CIS)"){:rel="external"}

A Managed service company (MSC) is an intermediary company where workers can provide services to clients.  Employers would pay the worker through the MSC. The MSC is responsible for paying workers' NICs and PAYE.

##Independent contractors: working out employment status
If most of the statements below apply to someone, it's likely that they're self-employed because they:

- put in bids or give quotes to get work
- have specific pieces of work or projects to do but decide how to do the work
- aren't under direct supervision when working
- can hire someone else to do the work
- submit invoices for the work they've done
- are responsible for paying their own NICs and tax
- don't get holiday or sick pay when they aren't working
- have to do unsatisfactory work again in their own time and at their own expense 
- are responsible for losses and taking profits from their work
- can provide services to a number of different clients or customers
- operate under a contract (sometimes known as a 'contract for services' or 'consultancy agreement') that uses terms like 'self-employed', 'consultant', or an 'independent contractor' 

*[NICs]: National Insurance contributions
*[NIC]: National Insurance contribution
*[CIS]: Construction Industry Scheme
*[MSC]: Managed service company
*[PAYE]: Pay As You Earn
table.title: Contractor

table.body:
A court or [employment tribunal](/employment-tribunals/taking-a-case-to-an-employment-tribunal "Employment tribunal") (known as an [industrial tribunal](http://www.employmenttribunalsni.co.uk/ "industrial tribunal"){:rel="external"} in Northern Ireland) can make a final decision on employment status. They will look at how the employment relationship between the person and the business works in practice.

HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC) may regard someone as self-employed for tax purposes. However, an employment tribunal or court may still make a decision that they are a worker or employee for employment rights purposes. 

*[HMRC]: HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: Legal decisions on employment status
